concept.title: DITA
concept.shortdesc: The Darwin Information Typing Architecture, or short, DITA, is an XML standard for authoring and publishing technical documentation. It's originally developed by IBM and now maintained by OASIS.

conbody.p: DITA allows semantic markup of technical documentation. This means that instead of defining how the documentation should look, authors define what the information represents and it then gets formatted appropriately for the platform it's viewed in.

DITA is a topic-based writing style. This means that one first writes self-contained topics which can be concepts (overviews of a concept, such as this article about DITA), tasks (step by step tutorials) or references (data tables etc.).
Topics later get grouped by DITA Maps (.ditamap files). In this step, references between topics can get created. This is usually the task of an information architect.

In the last step, these maps can get transformed into user-readable output. This can be PDF files, websites, or any other format imaginable. For that task, tools such as the DITA Open Toolkit get used.
